claim: Earth is a planet in the solar system

supporting.text: Earth orbits the Sun, which is a defining characteristic of a planet in the solar system.

attacks.text: Earth orbits the Sun, which is a defining characteristic of a planet in the solar system.
Not all objects orbiting the Sun are classified as planets; some are dwarf planets or other celestial bodies.
Earth meets all three criteria of the IAU definition of a planet: it orbits the Sun, has sufficient mass for hydrostatic equilibrium, and has cleared its orbit.
The IAU definition of a planet is controversial and not universally accepted by astronomers.
Despite some controversy, the IAU definition remains the most widely accepted standard for planetary classification.

supporting.text: Earth meets the International Astronomical Union's criteria for being classified as a planet.

attacks.text: Earth meets the International Astronomical Union's criteria for being classified as a planet.
The IAU's definition of a planet is controversial and not universally accepted among astronomers.
Despite controversy, the IAU's definition remains the most widely recognized standard for planetary classification.
Earth does not clear its orbital neighborhood of debris, which some argue disqualifies it from being a planet.
Earth's orbital neighborhood is sufficiently cleared to meet the IAU's practical interpretation of this criterion.

supporting.text: Earth is one of the eight recognized planets in the solar system, as confirmed by astronomical observations.

attacks.text: Earth is one of the eight recognized planets in the solar system, as confirmed by astronomical observations.
The definition of a planet is contested, and some astronomers argue that Earth does not meet all criteria.
The International Astronomical Union (IAU) has clearly defined a planet, and Earth meets all the criteria without ambiguity.
Some fringe theories suggest Earth is not a planet but a unique celestial body with special properties.
These fringe theories lack empirical evidence and are not accepted by the scientific community.

supporting.text: Earth's gravitational dominance in its orbital neighborhood qualifies it as a planet according to scientific consensus.

attacks.text: Earth's gravitational dominance in its orbital neighborhood qualifies it as a planet according to scientific consensus.
Gravitational dominance alone does not fully define a planet; other criteria like clearing its orbit must also be met.
Scientific consensus explicitly includes orbit-clearing as part of the definition, which Earth satisfies.
Some dwarf planets like Pluto also have gravitational dominance but are not classified as planets.
Pluto fails the orbit-clearing criterion, unlike Earth, which fully satisfies all planetary definitions.
